technology behind all of this is what we call containers and containers work as follows so the idea is that we have the
infrastructure layer so just our standard infrastructure a Windows PC or a Linux PC or just a machine we run an
operating system on top of that and on top of that operating system or that operating system has a capability called
container now what we can do all of a sudden we can then containerize our application and run that container on
that machine in complete isolation of any other container that runs on our machine now the fun thing about the
container is that it contains our application plus all its references to other stuff meaning that it makes
very easy for us to have multiple of these things running on our machine without polluting each other or yeah
more or less hitting each other and bumping into each other and making things broken so what we have is a
different way of virtualization then you normally have when you would do virtual machines because with virtual machines
we have this notion of hardware virtualization but we containers we have the notion of kernel level or operating
system virtualization meaning that we do not need to run a second operating system on our machine we can just
leverage the operating system that's already running now what's important to understand is
that if you create such an image then your image becomes dependent on the kernel on which you build it because you
can imagine that if you have a new version of a kernel that yeah you're sharing something you are using something that's part of the operating
system which is not virtualized well it's contained but not virtualized so that's the way you can run containers
on a Linux machine and the fun thing is no additional overhead with additional operating system now if we go further
and look at Windows containers then it's more or less the same we have this infrastructure on top of the infrastructure we have the windows host
